awd_titl_txt: Building Capacity: Polytechnic for All: STEM Undergraduate Success via an Inclusive Institution
awd_abstract_narration:
The Improving Undergraduate STEM Education: Hispanic-Serving Institutions Program (HSI Program) aims to enhance undergraduate STEM education and build capacity at HSIs. Projects supported by the HSI program will also generate new knowledge about how to achieve these aims.  This project at California State Polytechnic University, Pomona, will advance the aims of the HSI Program by developing and implementing a multi-faceted approach to enhance student learning and success in STEM. First, the project will compare the impact of two different motivational interventions on student learning.  One intervention targets students' sense of how the course material is personally relevant or useful in their lives; the other intervention helps students realize that worries about belonging in college are normal, transient, and improve over time. Second, the project will create opportunities for faculty to study, design, and use inclusive practices, including active learning. Third, the project will study the impact of a peer-led supplemental instruction program focused on second-year engineering courses. The project activities and outcomes can advance our understanding of how faculty learn to create an inclusive classroom. Moreover, the project can illuminate the impact that different approaches to inclusiveness have on students' academic success, motivation, and well-being. 

This project aims to promote creation of inclusive classroom environments. The project will employ two motivational interventions that seek to promote student STEM success in critical transition courses. One intervention focuses on increasing students' understanding of how the content is relevant; the other targets students' sense of social belonging in college-level STEM courses. To assess the efficacy of the motivation interventions, the project will use randomized, controlled trials to determine how the two psychosocial treatments affect the academic success and well-being of students enrolled in first year physics and calculus courses. The impact of faculty professional development efforts will be examined with mixed methods approaches, including pre-post surveys, teaching strategies inventories, and interviews. The impact of the peer-led supplemental instruction program will be determined by comparing outcomes for a matched set of students who do and do not participate in the program. Measures for this facet of the project include course grades, sense of self-efficacy, motivation, and content knowledge. This project will generate new knowledge about how to implement inclusive STEM teaching reforms anchored in an understanding of motivation and social-psychological factors that lead to increased student success in STEM.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A Science, Technology, Engineering or Mathematics (STEM) degree equips students to understand the universe, make informed public and private choices, and help solve problems. It can also serve as a catalyst for students to pursue their dreams and move up the social mobility ladder. However, for too many students, the pipeline to a STEM career ends too early. Nearly half of students entering college as STEM majors do not graduate with a STEM degree. Those who do not continue are often members of one or more marginalized groups, such as people from minoritized racial groups, people from more modest socioeconomic groups, veterans, and people who are the first generation in their family to attend college. A growing body of research suggests that the teaching practices traditionally used in STEM courses contribute to inequities in student outcomes.

 

Undergraduate students’ motivation and sense of belonging play an important role in their STEM success, so Cal Poly Pomona (CPP) took four important steps to help faculty create more inclusive classrooms. First, we conducted randomized, controlled trials in first year physics and calculus courses to determine the impact of a short motivation intervention focused on increasing students' understanding of how the course content is relevant to their lives. We found that doing just two assignments in which students reflect on how the course material might be useful to them, each requiring 15 minutes or less, increased students' sense of purpose for the course content, increased their midterm and final grades, and their sense of flourishing. Flourishing is a measure of a person's state of being free from illness and distress, their fulfillment in life, their sense of accomplishing meaningful and worthwhile tasks, and connecting deeply with others. 

A second goal of this project was to create a range of opportunities for faculty to study, design and use inclusive teaching practices, including active learning, better attending to student thinking, and using motivation informed teaching strategies. We found that STEM faculty are eager to learn inclusive teaching strategies and their students benefit when their instructors learn and use these strategies. Encouraging student motivation, using active learning techniques, and supporting students in difficulty were areas in which faculty wanted to learn. Over 600 faculty participated in various courses to learn more about creating inclusive classrooms, including two on Anti-racist teaching and learning, a course that is now publicly available. One of the courses offered was on motivating learners. We found that students whose math instructors participated in the course earned higher grades and were more likely to pass the class than students whose instructors did not take the course and achievement gaps were reduced. For Calculus in particular, we developed a set of freely available instructional materials that promote active learning and group problem solving. We found that the students of faculty using these materials had higher grades and higher passing rates compared to those who did not use them.

Because we were studying students’ motivation and belonging, we were well-positioned to understand the role the COVID-19 pandemic played on CPP students and STEM faculty. In-depth focus groups with STEM students revealed that interactive synchronous instruction was particularly helpful in increasing belonging for underrepresented students after the pandemic-related online transition. Furthermore, we found that students who coped with the pandemic by actively focusing on the problem (virtual learning during the pandemic) and looked for ways to handle it had increased cognitive engagement in virtual courses, higher well-being, and more post traumatic growth during the lockdown period of the pandemic compared to students who distracted themselves or tried to avoid the problem. Interviews with STEM faculty revealed deep caring for students, which was expressed as empathy, liking, respect, acceptance, or taking students seriously. This sense of caring for students was evidenced by the variety of accommodations that instructors made to their courses and teaching methods including providing increased academic support, flexibility, added effort to improve instruction, or reaching out to students personally.

Finally, we implemented a peer-led, Supplemental Instruction program focused on second-year engineering courses. We found that supplemental instruction can help increase student success, but students benefit most when there is strong buy-in from faculty leading the supported courses and the support program is offered at a time that aligns with students’ schedules.

Overall, the work from this project was important because we advanced our understanding of how faculty learn to create an inclusive, yet still rigorous classroom and the impact that varying approaches to inclusiveness have on students’ academic success, motivation, and well-being at a STEM-intensive Hispanic Serving Polytechnic University.
